hints.title: Computational Closure ⇔ EFT Validity
hints.content:
1529: :label: thm-computational-closure-eft-validity
1530: 
1531: An effective field theory at scale $\Lambda$ is valid if and only if the RG transformation from the UV cutoff $\Lambda_{\text{UV}}$ to $\Lambda$ satisfies computational closure.
1532: 
1533: **Formal statement:** Let $\mathcal{T}_{\text{UV}}$ be the microscopic theory at scale $\Lambda_{\text{UV}}$ with ε-machine $(\Sigma_{\varepsilon}^{\text{UV}}, T_{\varepsilon}^{\text{UV}})$. Let $\mathcal{T}_{\text{EFT}}$ be the effective theory at scale $\Lambda$ with ε-machine $(\Sigma_{\varepsilon}^{\text{EFT}}, T_{\varepsilon}^{\text{EFT}})$.
1534: 
1535: The EFT is valid if:
1536: 
1537: $$
1538: \Sigma_{\varepsilon}^{\text{EFT}} = \pi(\Sigma_{\varepsilon}^{\text{UV}})
1539: 
1540: $$
1541: 
1542: where $\pi$ is the projection induced by the RG flow $\mathcal{RG}_{b}$ with $b = \Lambda_{\text{UV}}/\Lambda$.
1543: 
1544: **Error bound:** The observables satisfy:
1545: 
1546: $$
1547: |\langle \mathcal{O} \rangle_{\text{UV}} - \langle \mathcal{O} \rangle_{\text{EFT}}| \leq C \cdot D_{\text{KL}}(\mu_{\text{EFT}} \| \mathcal{R}_b \mu_{\text{UV}})^{1/2}
1548: 
1549: $$
1550: 
1551: (Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-observable-invariance-closure`).
1552: 
1553: **Breakdown:** The EFT breaks down when computational closure fails, i.e., when the macro-ε-machine cannot be obtained by coarse-graining the micro-ε-machine. This happens when:

1526: Effective field theory (EFT) relies on the assumption that low-energy physics decouples from high-energy details. Closure theory makes this rigorous.
1527:

1529: :label: thm-computational-closure-eft-validity

Let $\mathcal{T}_{\text{EFT}}$ be the effective theory at scale $\Lambda$ with ε-machine $(\Sigma_{\varepsilon}^{\text{EFT}}, T_{\varepsilon}^{\text{EFT}})$.
1534: 
1535: The EFT is valid if:
1536: 
1537: $$
1538: \Sigma_{\varepsilon}^{\text{EFT}} = \pi(\Sigma_{\varepsilon}^{\text{UV}})
1539: 
1540: $$
1541: 
1542: where $\pi$ is the projection induced by the RG flow $\mathcal{RG}_{b}$ with $b = \Lambda_{\text{UV}}/\Lambda$.
1543: 
1544: **Error bound:** The observables satisfy:
1545: 
1546: $$
1547: |\langle \mathcal{O} \rangle_{\text{UV}} - \langle \mathcal{O} \rangle_{\text{EFT}}| \leq C \cdot D_{\text{KL}}(\mu_{\text{EFT}} \| \mathcal{R}_b \mu_{\text{UV}})^{1/2}
1548: 
1549: $$
1550:

hints.label: prop-gauge-invariant-observables-preserved
hints.title: Gauge-Invariant Observables Preserved
hints.content:
1561: :label: prop-gauge-invariant-observables-preserved
1562: 
1563: Wilson loops $W_C$ are **gauge-invariant** observables. Under computational closure, they are preserved:
1564: 
1565: $$
1566: \langle W_C \rangle_{\text{micro}} = \langle W_{\tilde{C}} \rangle_{\text{macro}} + O(D_{\text{KL}}^{1/2})
1567: 
1568: $$
1569: 
1570: where $\tilde{C}$ is the coarse-grained loop on the block lattice.
1571: 
1572: **Proof:**
1573: 
1574: **Step 1:** Wilson loops are defined via parallel transport:
1575: 
1576: $$
1577: W_C = \frac{1}{N_c} \text{Tr} \prod_{e \in C} U_e
1578: 
1579: $$
1580: 
1581: (Definition 5.1.1 in [08_lattice_qft_framework.md](08_lattice_qft_framework.md)).
1582: 
1583: **Step 2:** Under block-spin transformation, the macro-link variable $\tilde{U}_{\tilde{e}}$ is defined via:
1584: 
1585: $$
1586: \tilde{U}_{\tilde{e}} = \arg\min_{\hat{U}} \sum_{\{e : e \subset \tilde{e}\}} |U_e - \hat{U}|^2
1587: 
1588: $$
1589: 
1590: (Definition 9.5.1 in [08_lattice_qft_framework.md](08_lattice_qft_framework.md)).
1591: 
1592: **Step 3:** For gauge-invariant quantities, the coarse-graining commutes with the trace:
1593: 
1594: $$
1595: \text{Tr} \prod_{\tilde{e} \in \tilde{C}} \tilde{U}_{\tilde{e}} \approx \text{Tr} \prod_{e \in C} U_e
1596: 
1597: $$

1558: ### 9.2. Wilson Loops and Gauge Invariance
1559: 
1560: :::{prf:proposition} Gauge-Invariant Observables Preserved
1561: :label: prop-gauge-invariant-observables-preserved
1562: 
1563: Wilson loops $W_C$ are **gauge-invariant** observables. Under computational closure, they are preserved:
1564: 
1565: $$
1566: \langle W_C \rangle_{\text{micro}} = \langle W_{\tilde{C}} \rangle_{\text{macro}} + O(D_{\text{KL}}^{1/2})
1567: 
1568: $$
1569: 
1570: where $\tilde{C}$ is the coarse-grained loop on the block lattice.
1571: 
1572: **Proof:**
1573: 
1574: **Step 1:** Wilson loops are defined via parallel transport:
1575: 
1576: $$
1577: W_C = \frac{1}{N_c} \text{Tr} \prod_{e \in C} U_e
1578: 
1579: $$
1580: 
1581: (Definition 5.1.1 in [08_lattice_qft_framework.md](08_lattice_qft_framework.md)).
1582: 
1583: **Step 2:** Under block-spin transformation, the macro-link variable $\tilde{U}_{\tilde{e}}$ is defined via:
1584: 
1585: $$
1586: \tilde{U}_{\tilde{e}} = \arg\min_{\hat{U}} \sum_{\{e : e \subset \tilde{e}\}} |U_e - \hat{U}|^2
1587: 
1588: $$
1589: 
1590: (Definition 9.5.1 in [08_lattice_qft_framework.md](08_lattice_qft_framework.md)).
1591: 
1592: **Step 3:** For gauge-invariant quantities, the coarse-graining commutes with the trace:
1593: 
1594: $$
1595: \text{Tr} \prod_{\tilde{e} \in \tilde{C}} \tilde{U}_{\tilde{e}} \approx \text{Tr} \prod_{e \in C} U_e
1596: 
1597: $$

hints.label: thm-beta-function-computational-closure
hints.title: Beta Function from Computational Closure
hints.content:
1607: :label: thm-beta-function-computational-closure
1608: 
1609: The beta function for the gauge coupling:
1610: 
1611: $$
1612: \beta(g) = -\frac{g^3}{16\pi^2} \cdot \frac{11N_c - 2N_f}{3}
1613: 
1614: $$
1615: 
1616: arises from requiring computational closure of the block-spin transformation on the ε-machine.
1617: 
1618: **Derivation:**
1619: 
1620: **Step 1:** The micro-ε-machine has transition probabilities determined by the BAOAB kernel with gauge coupling $g$.
1621: 
1622: **Step 2:** Under block-spin transformation $\mathcal{R}_b$, the macro-ε-machine has transition probabilities determined by a modified BAOAB kernel.
1623: 
1624: **Step 3:** Computational closure requires the macro-kernel to have the same functional form as the micro-kernel, but with renormalized coupling $g' = g + \delta g$.
1625: 
1626: **Step 4:** Solving for $\delta g$ such that the macro-Wilson action matches the micro-Wilson action (via dimensional regularization and background-field Ward identity, § 9.5) yields:
1627: 
1628: $$
1629: g' = g \left(1 - \frac{g^2}{16\pi^2} \cdot \frac{11N_c - 2N_f}{3} \cdot \log b \right) + O(g^5)
1630: 
1631: $$
1632: 
1633: **Step 5:** Taking the continuum limit $b = e^{\delta t}$ gives:
1634: 
1635: $$
1636: \beta(g) = \lim_{\delta t \to 0} \frac{g' - g}{\delta t} = -\frac{g^3}{16\pi^2} \cdot \frac{11N_c - 2N_f}{3}
1637: 
1638: $$

hints.label: thm-continuum-limit-fixed-point
hints.title: Continuum Limit as Fixed Point
hints.content:
1648: :label: thm-continuum-limit-fixed-point
1649: 
1650: The continuum limit $a \to 0$ of the Fractal Gas lattice QFT corresponds to flowing to the UV fixed point $g^* = 0$ under repeated RG transformations.
1651: 
1652: At the fixed point, the ε-machine is **scale-invariant**: all causal states are isomorphic across scales.
1653: 
1654: **Proof:**
1655: 
1656: **Step 1:** Asymptotic freedom implies $g(a) \to 0$ as $a \to 0$ (Corollary {prf:ref}`cor-asymptotic-freedom-trivial-fixed-point`).
1657: 
1658: **Step 2:** At $g = 0$, the theory is free (no interactions), hence the ε-machine is trivial: all walkers evolve independently.
1659: 
1660: **Step 3:** The free ε-machine is self-similar under coarse-graining (independent systems remain independent under averaging), hence is a fixed point.
